titleInfo.title: John Brother Cade Jr. oral history interview

mods.abstract: Cade discusses a typical day at McKinley High School, including classroom activities, clubs, dances, sports, the importance of academic achievement, and buildings partnerships with parents to help students achieve. He discusses the legacy of McKinley High School, the strength of its community, the success of its alumni, changes since the time he taught there, and the lack of discipline among children.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.0643; A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes; A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room; Interview conducted by Shawnda Hollins and Carmen Posey.

John Brother Cade Jr. was born on the campus of Prairie View A&M University, Texas, to John B. Cade Sr. and Jessie Mae Maben Cade. He attended Southern University Laboratory High School and later graduated from Southern University. Cade taught at McKinley High School in Baton Rouge, La., between 1961 and 1964. He also was a teacher at Scotlandville High School and assistant principal at Capitol High School. His father, John B. Cade Sr., was the first principal at Southern University Laboratory High School and University Dean and Director of Extension Services at Southern University (1939-1961).

name.namePart: Louisiana State University (Baton Rouge, La.). T. Harry Williams Center for Oral History
